Hi

To become a certified SAP ERP MM (Materials Management) Consultant, you need to follow the official SAP Learning Journey for SAP Certified Application Associate – Procurement with SAP ERP 6.0 EhP7 (exam code: C_TSCM52_67). The structured path includes foundational ERP courses, MM-specific configuration and procurement courses, and exam preparation modules available on SAP Learning(1) and SAP Learning Journeys(5)  website

entry.title: Some user can not see the price for purchase order
entry.content:
Is there BADI that can meet the following business scenarios:
When displaying purchase orders, for certain users such as purchasing users, the price and amount of the purchase order can be viewed normally, while for other users such as warehousing users, the price and amount of the purchase order are not displayed.

entry.title: Re: Some user can not see the price for purchase order
entry.content:
Hi,

Please use this Business Add-In (BAdI) Change of Field Control for Purchase Order Items (MM_PUR_S4_PO_FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE) is used in the Purchasing (MM-PUR-PO) component.

You use this BAdI to change the field control in the purchase order apps .

You can use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE to modify the properties of specific fields that appear on the user interface of the apps:

  • Manage Purchase Orders on item level in the section Process Control
  • Create Purchase Order - Advanced on item level on the tabs Delivery and Invoice.

The SAP GUI transactions ME21N, ME22N, ME23N are also affected by this
BAdI.
You can make the fields hidden, read-only, mandatory, or optional as per
your requirements.

Using the BAdI you can change the field control properties for the
following attributes:

  • Goods Receipt GOODSRECEIPTISEXPECTED
  • Non-Valuated Goods Receipt GOODSRECEIPTISNONVALUATED
  • Invoice Receipt INVOICEISEXPECTED
  • Goods-Receipt-Based Invoice Verification INVOICEISGOODSRECEIPTBASED
  • Final Invoice ISFINALLYINVOICED
  • Delivery Completed ISCOMPLETELYDELIVERED
  • Tax Code TAXCODE
  • Net Price Amount NETPRICEAMOUNT
  • Expected Value EXPECTEDOVERALLLIMITAMOUNT
  • Overall Limit OVERALLLIMITAMOUNT
  • Contract for Limit PURCONTRACTFOROVERALLLIMIT
  • Service Performer SERVICEPERFORMER
  • Incoterms INCOTERMSCLASSIFICATION
  • Shipping Instructions SHIPPINGINSTRUCTION

Refer to KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/3268822

Thank you,

SAP Support

entry.title: LLM大语言模型常见概念介绍
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

你有没有好奇过，当你问ChatGPT一个问题时，它的"大脑"里到底发生了什么？

今天我们就来拆解这个黑盒子，用最简单的方式理解AI是如何工作的。

 

LLM的基本组成：AI的"大脑"构造

LLM主要由两个核心部分组成：

神经网络（Neural Network）：

神经网络本体由数以千亿个相互连接的"神经元"组成

每个神经元都存储着微小的"知识片段"

神经元之间互相连接，可以传递和组合信息

神经元的数量就是我们常说的LLM模型的参数数量，一般情况来说，神经元越多，模型越聪明（这个规律也被称为Scaling Law）

 

翻译器（Tokenizer）：语言的"耳朵"和"嘴巴"

翻译器就像是大脑的感官系统，负责在人类语言和机器语言之间进行转换：

"耳朵"功能：将听到的内容（例如文本）转换成大脑能理解的"神经信号"（数字向量）

"嘴巴"功能：将大脑的"思考结果"重新翻译成我们能理解的自然语言

就像我们听到声音后大脑要先处理成神经信号才能理解一样，LLM也需要这个翻译器来"听懂"和"说出"人话。

 

LLM常见应用场景详解

训练（Training）：LLM的"求学过程"

就像一个婴儿学习说话的过程

刚被创建的神经网络内神经元的内容是随机的，需要经过训练，修改神经元内容，才会让LLM变聪明

而训练过程就像玩猜字游戏，训练员给到一段文字，让大脑猜测这段文字的下一个字是什么，如果猜错了，训练员就会根据猜测结果与正确答案的偏差程度来修改神经元内容

这样，3个字的输入数据ABC就可以产生2次训练结果，分别是根据A来猜测B，和根据AB来猜测C

这个过程中，神经元内存放的信息会持续改变，LLM也就在这个过程中变得更聪明

 

但纯文本训练而来的LLM的对话风格，价值观等是由训练数据决定的，错误价值观很容易造成严重后果

而我们很难人为判断数据是否合适，进而“规训”LLM的价值观

所以有一种特殊训练方式：

RLHF（人类反馈强化学习）- AI的"价值观教育"

就是让LLM对一个问题生成多个回答，由人类标注哪个回答更好，来训练LLM，以让LLM的回答更符合人类倾向

如果你在使用AI时遇到它问你两类答案哪个你更喜欢，不用怀疑，你正在训练LLM

 

常见名词解释：

推理（Inference）：LLM的"即时思考"

就是LLM接收信息，返回结果的过程

这个过程中，神经元内存放的信息是不变的

 

微调（Fine-tuning）：LLM的"继续教育"

就是以较低成本训练，优化LLM。成本降序排列如下:

  • 可以按照正常训练模式，继续修改全量神经元的信息，但这样需要大量数据和算力
  • 也可以将部分神经元冻结，后续训练只会选择性的更新未冻结神经元的信息
  • 还可以添加一组辅助神经网络，新训练只修改辅助神经网络，不同任务对应不同的辅助神经网络

 

还有一些不修改参数，不进行训练的优化方式：

1.角色扮演提示：通过告诉LLM要扮演什么角色来快速的规范LLM的回答

例如：

普通问法：翻译这句话：How are you

优化问法：你是一名15年经验的专业英文翻译，请翻译这句话

 

2.零样本提示：通过明确任务描述与要求的方式来优化表现

普通问法："翻译这句话：How are you"

优化问法："请将以下中文翻译成地道的英文，注意保持原意和语气：How are you"

 

3.少样本提示：在零样本的基础上给出几组范例

例如：

"请按照以下格式回答：

例子1：问题：苹果是什么颜色？回答：苹果通常是红色或绿色的。

例子2：问题：猫会飞吗？回答：猫不会飞，它们是陆地动物。

现在请回答：狗喜欢什么？"

 

4.思维链提示：以思维链的方式解决问题，并作为范例发送

例如：

"问题：咖啡店有23个顾客，又来了15个，然后走了9个，现在有多少顾客？

思考过程：最开始有23个顾客，来了15个后是23+15=38个，走了9个后是38-9=29个。

答案：29个顾客。

现在请用同样的方式解决这个问题：

学校有87个学生，转走了12个，又转来了8个，现在有多少学生？"

 

总结

LLM就像一个拥有千亿神经元的"大脑"，配备翻译器来理解和输出人类语言。

它通过训练不断学习知识，通过推理回答问题，还可以用微调和提示优化等方式提升表现。

简单来说，LLM就是在通过数学的方式模拟人类的学习、思考和交流过程。

Further also refer to below SAP Note and check me.sap.com portal through S-user id of your customer.

2671448 - How to locate our SAP CSM or CEE contact - SAP for Me

In SAP for Me go to Users & Contacts Overview tab to find SAP Contacts. The same contacts can also be found on the Product Detail Page for specific products (see KBA 3222501).

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration - Upgrade Readiness Design Guidelines/Best Practices for Future Readiness
entry.content:
Introduction

Have you ever wondered where to start to understand the benefits of upgrade readiness design guidelines for your cloud integration system and how to achieve them? Then this blog post is for you! It brings you in-depth insights into the upgrade readiness concept and its implementation, with resources to help make your integration artifacts, prominently Groovy scripts, future-proof.

Whether you're developing integration scenarios in SAP Integration Suite or refining existing ones, this is your guide to ensuring long-term stability, maintainability, and resilience - even in the face of major runtime upgrades.

In this blog post, you will understand the detailed aspects of upgrade readiness, its objectives, principles and how to leverage in the integration flow tooling. With the 7.45 version in NEO and 6.72/8.36 in Cloud foundry release,  SAP Cloud Integration provides a upgrade readiness feature.

Why is Upgrade Readiness Essential?

One of the most powerful features of SAP Cloud Integration is the Groovy flow step, which allows developers to write custom Groovy scripts to solve complex problems efficiently. However, these scripts can create risks for future upgrades, especially when they rely on:

  • Unsupported system classes.
  • Internal Apache Camel framework classes.
  • Undocumented Java libraries.

Using these internal or unsupported classes may not only result in incompatibility during major runtime upgrades but can make the system fragile and prone to failures, something many of you may have experienced during previous major version upgrades.

What is Upgrade Readiness?

Upgrade readiness is a set of best practices, guidelines, rules, or tools designed to ensure scripts are clean, consistent, and ready for future upgrades. It promotes a development approach that helps maintain the stability and reliability of integration artifacts and minimizes the risk of breakdown during major runtime version upgrades in SAP Integration Suite.

Here’s how upgrade readiness can help:

  1. Restrict Usage of Internal APIs: Avoid APIs that are unsupported or pose risks during upgrades.
  2. Identify Violations in Groovy Scripts: Detect and fix problematic script patterns, such as unused imports or usage of internal APIs.
  3. Encourage Using Recommended Libraries and Standards: Build scripts that align with SAP's recommended practices and approved APIs.

Upgrade Readiness Guidelines

Adhering to these guidelines promotes a robust, scalable architecture that withstands future system upgrades. Let’s explore key considerations.

Remove Unused Imports

Unused imports create unnecessary complications during software or runtime upgrades:

  • Avoid compilation/runtime errors: Unused imports might reference deprecated libraries or classes, potentially breaking the script.
  • Eliminate visual clutter: It helps streamline script functionality while avoiding confusion about dependencies.

Best Practice: Scan all Groovy scripts for unused imports and remove them to ensure clean and efficient code.

Use Recommended Libraries and Classes

A crucial step in creating upgrade-ready artifacts is using only recommended or SAP-approved libraries and APIs:

  • Avoid Internal Classes: Replace direct usage of internal classes (e.g., Apache Camel) with SAP-provided APIs and extensions.
  • Leverage supported libraries: Always rely on SAP APIs for safe system interactions, reducing risks from dependency issues during updates.
  • Bundle custom libraries carefully: If a critical library isn’t provided by SAP, include it as part of your integration flow. However, be aware that this may impact flow size and startup performance.
  • Restrict OS/Network access: Avoid direct file/system operations; use alternatives provided by SAP.

Examples of unsupported classes to avoid:

  • System.exit() or TimeZone.setDefault()
  • Direct access to environment variables using System.getenv() or System.getProperty()
  • Console outputs like System.out.println()

Instead, use alternatives like SAP API com.sap.it.script.system.Properties for environment-safe interactions.

Refer KBA to know the list of incompatible internal classes.

Plan Proactive Cleanup of Existing Scripts

As part of preparing your system for future upgrades, ensure current scripts are compliant with upgrade readiness guidelines.

  • Start cleanup processes for existing artifacts adhering to the new framework.
  • Focus on creating awareness among development teams about unsupported script patterns.
  • Get familiar with the upgrade readiness toolset in SAP Integration Suite.

Upgrade Readiness Objectives and Strategy

Upgrade readiness is more than just avoiding future system breakdowns; it’s about establishing a future-proof integration development model.

Objectives:

  1. Enable future proofing: Build robust integration artifacts that are immune to frequent version upgrades.
  2. Ensure maintainability: Maintain clean, stable, and compatible integration scripts.
  3. Reduce upgrade risks: Proactively address dependencies on unsupported libraries and APIs.

Strategy:

  • Introduce upgrade compliance guidelines for current SAP Cloud Integration stacks (NEO, CF) to foster awareness.
  • Collaborate with teams to initiate self-service cleanup of existing artifacts.
  • Provide training and resources to ensure developers are well-versed in upgraded best practices.

Upgrade Readiness Principles

  1. Code Cleanliness

    • Remove unused imports.
    • Write concise, maintainable scripts.

  2. Avoid Unsupported APIs and Classes

    • Avoid internal, deprecated, or system-level APIs.
    • Refrain from direct OS manipulations.

  3. Use Recommended Libraries and APIs

    • Use SAP-provided or approved APIs.
    • Replace unsupported libraries with standard alternatives.

  4. Plan for Future Compatibility

    • Design artifacts resilient to runtime upgrades.
    • Ensure compatibility with future software updates.

  5. Reduce Code and Visual Clutter

    • Eliminate unnecessary logs and code blocks.
    • Keep scripts streamlined and easy to understand.

  6. Enable Proactive Cleanup

    • Regularly review and update integration artifacts.
    • Clean up older stacks like NEO and CF deployments.

  7. Avoid Operating System Manipulations

    • Avoid direct OS interactions.
    • Use platform-provided APIs for secure operations.

  8. Train Teams on Best Practices

    • Educate developers on best practices.
    • Promote awareness of upgrade readiness tools.

  9. Utilize Upgrade Readiness Tools

    • Use tools to monitor for violations.
    • Proactively identify and resolve issues.

Implementing these principles ensures stable, future-proof integration artifacts.

Steps to Apply Upgrade Readiness

Applying upgrade readiness and future-proofing your integration artifacts involves following a set of best practices and utilizing the tools provided within the integration platform. Below, we outline the steps to achieve this:

Access Integration Settings Page

    • Navigate to the Integration Settings page.
    • Here, you will find the newly introduced upgrade readiness design guidelines, which are activated by default

Open Integration Flow Editor

    • Access the integration flow editor where you design and manage your integration artifacts.
    • You will notice the same set of upgrade readiness design guidelines applicable here.

Execute Guidelines and Check Compliance Status

    • Execute the guidelines to see the compliance status of your integration artifacts.
    • Specifically check for non-compliant Groovy flow steps. Analysis feature will show the list of affected groovy scripts. Check the version of the groovy script as well.

Open the Script Editor

    • Open the script editor to examine the issues highlighted in the problems view.
    • Note that upgrading to Groovy step 2.x can fix crucial violations related to internal Camel and stack class usage.

 


Apply Fixes and Recommendations

    • Follow the suggested fixes and recommendations to make your Groovy scripts future-ready.
    • Save the Groovy script by clicking Apply and then close the editor to return to the integration flow editor.

 

Save the Integration Flow

    • Save your integration flow to ensure that all changes are persisted.
    • Verify the version of the Groovy flow step is updated to 2.x.

Re-evaluate Compliance

    • After applying the upgrades, execute the guidelines again to ensure that the previously violated Groovy steps are now compliant.

Important Note

  • You can leverage the public OData Remote APIs to read, execute and download the guidelines at the integration flow artifact level. This will promote the automation.
  • Refer to the documentation for details: Integration Flow Design Guidelines.

Why Groovy Script 2.x?

Upgrading to Groovy script 2.x provides several benefits:

  • Future-Ready Scripts: Automatic fixes for incompatible libraries and classes prepare your scripts for future major version runtime and software upgrades.
  • Advanced Groovy Features: Utilizes Groovy runtime 4.0.29, providing access to modern language elements such as switch expressions and other capabilities. You can refer the groovy 4.0.29 for more details.

Handling Non-Compatibility

If the updated version of the Groovy step does not yield the expected result then take the below measures.

  1. Downgrade Groovy Script: You can downgrade the Groovy script step and revert to the older version.
  2. Create a ServiceNow ticket : Document the issue and create a ticket using the component LOD-HCI-PI-WT-IFL for further assistance. Issue will be fixed as per the SLA.
  3. Adapt Processes: Adapt your business processes to accommodate the upgraded script to stay prepared for future upgrades. You should strive to be on the major version of the script step.

By following these steps, you can ensure that your integration artifacts are compliant with the latest guidelines and ready for future upgrades.

What’s coming next

  • Upgrade Readiness Guidelines for JavaScript.
  • Execute Design Guidelines Automatically on Artifact Save.
  • Block Artifact Deployment if Guidelines Are Violated, Governed by Tenant Administrator.
  • Central Dashboard Displaying All Incompatible Scripts at Tenant Level.

Share your feedback in the comment section on these upcoming innovations and provide your remarks on the prioritization.

Other source of material

  • Upgrade groovy script
  • new design guideline: recommended classes 
  • KBA Article

I hope you find the enhancements in this blog post beneficial. If you have any questions or feedback, please leave a comment.

entry.title: 7 Critical Risks Ignored in SAP S/4HANA Migration Projects — and How to Mitigate Them
entry.content:
Migrations to SAP S/4HANA continue to grow globally, yet many projects fail due to predictable risks that are often neglected. I share here the main critical points I observe in practice that PMs and IT leaders should anticipate from the blueprint phase.

1. Lack of Clear Definition of Technical and Functional Scope

In S/4HANA projects, scope changes happen naturally. The problem arises when there is no structured documentation, RACI matrix, or governance to approve these changes. Mitigation: Prioritized backlog + active Change Advisory Board (CAB).

2. Absence of a Data Strategy (Late Data Migration)

Data migration usually starts too late—and becomes the major bottleneck at Go-Live. Mitigation: Initiate Data Assessment early; structure Data Mapping + multiple planned mock cycles.

3. Underestimation of Integrations with Legacy Systems

Poorly documented interfaces compromise performance and stability. Mitigation: Updated integration catalog, mandatory End-to-End (E2E) testing, and pre-Go-Live monitoring.

4. Failures in Alignment Across Business Areas

Organizational silos generate rework and contradictory decisions. Mitigation: Weekly governance meetings, formally appointed business owners, and constant alignment meetings.

5. Overcustomization (Customizing When Standard Solutions Suffice)

Excessive Z custom code reduces scalability and increases maintenance costs. Mitigation: Implement a strict “fit-to-standard-first” policy.

6. Lack of a Robust Cutover and Go-Live Plan

A poorly coordinated cutover can lead to operational downtime and financial losses. Mitigation: Detailed project plan + mandatory cutover rehearsal + clear owner assigned per activity.

7. Flaws in the Training and Change Management Plan

SAP S/4HANA is not just technology: it's organizational change. Mitigation: Well-structured Change Management plan, role-based training (by job function), and continuous communication.

 

Conclusion

With the right combination of governance, risk management, and alignment between IT and business, the migration to SAP S/4HANA can be a predictable process with high positive impact.

If you have practical cases or recent challenges, share them in the comments—let's learn together.

SAP Integration Strategy, SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics SAP ERP SAP Commercial Project Management

entry.title: Re: Change financial statement versions in Company Profit...
entry.content:
Hello @suyoung_choi3 ,

Please find the following help document for your reference:

Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) | SAP Help Portal

Semantic tags are textual identifiers used to highlight key figures in financial statement versions (FSVs). These tags are linked to FSV structures, easing the calculation of metrics and key performance indicators (KPIs) for analytical reporting. Beyond FSV YPS2, you can construct your own FSV using the semantic tags from the SAP template, and assign your own GL Account. These custom tags need to be associated with the correct financial statement versions (FSVs).

You need to assign your own FSV to the semantic tags mentioned in the help link, or change the related node in the YPS2 related to these semantic tags.

Kind Regards,

Hi Community,

" 

  • Leverage Global Patterns early in your project planning - these non-visual building blocks like draft handling and navigation patterns are often overlooked but critical for enterprise applications   
  • Evaluate standard floorplans against your use cases before building custom solutions - List Report and Object Page patterns handle the majority of business scenarios. Together with the extension points provided by SAP Fiori elements, they can often meet your requirements with minimal effort
  • Use Custom Pages for more creative app layouts - if the target picture of your application is too far from the standard floorplans, opt for custom page creation using building blocks and global patterns to get the benefits of the metadata-driven UIs, or leverage freestyle SAPUI5 to achieve your goal. "

 

Thanks for your selfless sharing, it really help us a lot.

 

🙂

Regards,

ZFiori.

entry.title: Integration Modernization @ SAP TechEd - A Recap
entry.content:
The Integration Modernization Team was part of this year’s TechEd event in Berlin. 

Let’s check some highlights, especially the workshops in the context of integration modernization with SAP BTP Integration Suite.

IN161 | Modernize and transform your integration to the cloud

This Workshop gave us the opportunity to understand how companies can migrate from SAP Process Orchestration to the SAP Integration Suite.”

  • Assess and Plan: Evaluate existing scenarios and estimate migration effort with built-in assessment tools.
  • Automate Migration: Use semi-automated tooling and pattern-based templates to accelerate transformation.
  • Ensure Reliability: Leverage cloud pipelines for guaranteed delivery, error handling, and restart capabilities.

Content: https://github.com/SAP-samples/teched2025-IN161

IN163 | Implement Exactly Once In-Order Delivery in SAP Integration

This Workshop was focused on ensuring data consistency in message exchange by implementing Exactly Once In-Order (EOIO) delivery within SAP Integration Suite.

  • EOIO Concept: Guarantees messages are delivered without duplication and in their original sequence.
  • Implementation Options:
    • Exclusive Queues in Cloud Integration.
    • Partitioned Queues using Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) for high-scale scenarios.

Content: https://github.com/SAP-samples/teched2025-IN163

IN165 | Experience Event-Driven Integration with Advanced Event Mesh

In this Workshop we explored how SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh enables scalable, secure event-driven architectures with features like event replay, filtering, and multi-protocol support.

  • Core Concepts: Learn queues, topics, and filtering to build robust event-driven solutions.
  • Advanced Features: Explore event replay, distributed tracing, and fine-grained filtering for complex scenarios.
  • Enterprise Scale: AEM supports multi-cloud and on-premise deployments, offering high performance, security, and protocol support (JMS, REST, AMQP, MQTT).

Content: https://github.com/SAP-samples/teched2025-IN165

IN302 | Run Integration Scenarios in Private Landscapes with Edge Integration Cell

This Depp Dive explained how to extend SAP Integration Suite to private environments using Edge Integration Cell, enabling hybrid integration scenarios with full control and compliance.

  • Private Deployment: Run integration flows in your own data center or private cloud for sensitive workloads.
  • Hybrid Architecture: Combine cloud-based integration with on-premise execution for flexibility and security.
  • Enterprise Readiness: Ensure governance, monitoring, and lifecycle management across distributed landscapes.

Content: 

IN166 | Central Monitoring of Integration Scenarios with SAP Cloud ALM

This workshop gave us the opportunity to see how SAP Cloud ALM provides a central cockpit for monitoring integration scenarios across hybrid landscapes.

  • Integration & Exception Monitoring: Get an overview of failed messages and exceptions across SAP Integration Suite and connected systems.
  • Health Monitoring: Track critical resources like JMS queues and expiring certificates to prevent disruptions.
  • End-to-End Visibility: Drill down to single message details and jump context-sensitively to local monitoring for issue resolution.
  • Alerts & Notifications: Activate alerts and receive automated email notifications for proactive incident handling.

Content: https://github.com/SAP-samples/teched2025-IN161

 

There’s a lot to look forward, and we’ll see what 2026 brings with it:

SAP Innovation Guide: SAP Innovation Guide 

Integration Suite RoadMap: Integration Suite Road Map 

SAP Integration Modernization Community: SAP Integration Modernization Community 

We’d love to hear your thoughts and experiences with SAP Integration Suite. What challenges are you facing? How can we help you unlock the full potential of your IT ecosystem? Feel free to reach out to us via SAP Integration Services.

#Modernize #Integrate #Innovate – SAP Integration Modernization TEAM

entry.title: Streamlined Kyma deployment for CAP applications
entry.content:
SAP BTP, Kyma runtime (a fully managed cloud-native Kubernetes application runtime based on the open-source "Kyma" project) enables developers to deploy highly scalable, modular, and secure microservices. The SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model supports Kyma deployments as one of the recommended approaches in the SAP BTP Developer’s Guide

What’s New

In the November release of CAP, we have introduced several key improvements that significantly simplify the deployment of CAP applications to Kyma.

Here is a quick look at the changes:

  1. Streamlined project setup: The new cds add kyma command quickly configures your Kyma project and serves as the central entry point for configuring deployments to Kyma.
  2. Interactive credential handling: When using cds up -2 k8s, you’ll receive prompts for any missing registry credentials on your Kyma cluster, eliminating guesswork during deployment.
  3. Automatic UI5 build: The cds up -2 k8s command now automatically builds your SAP UI5 applications, removing an extra manual step from your workflow.
  4. Intelligent build optimization: Builds now trigger only when artifact changes are detected, eliminating unnecessary build cycles and notably speeding up your deployment process.
  5. Simplified tooling: The standalone containerize tool (also known as ctz) is no longer required. The cds up -2 k8s command handles containerization directly reducing external dependencies

Ready to try it out? Make sure to have the latest cli version with npm i -g @SAP/cds-dk@latest, also check out the updated documentation  and our release notes for complete details on these improvements.

As always, if you have any questions, do not hesitate to reach out to us on cap@sap.com

entry.title: Re: Enter Trading Partner in "Post Incoming Payments" App
entry.content:
Trading partner input in Journal Entry (Including app Post Incoming Payments) is controlled by Document Type, which depends on two customizing settings in the SSCUI 101522 - Define Document Types: Inter-company Posting and Enter Trading Partner.

Document Type DZ - Customer Payment, used in Post Incoming Payment, does not have these two settings enabled by default, so Trading Partner will not show up for input.

Please review KBA 3060863 - "Trading Partner field in Journal Entry document" and configure your Document Type settings accordingly to allow Trading Partner input for your business needs.

entry.title: Determining the Right Owner in SAP Sales Cloud V2 Using Account Hierarchy
entry.content:
Sales teams work best when every opportunity, lead, or order lands in the hands of the right person. The challenge is that ownership isn’t always straightforward. Accounts have parent-child relationships. Territories change. Local teams handle one part of the business while regional teams oversee the rest. And when ownership isn’t assigned correctly, work slows down, follow-ups slip, and revenue gets left on the table.

SAP Sales Cloud V2 now includes a new determination step that tackles this neatly: Owner determination based on the Account Hierarchy. It’s simple in concept but hugely practical in day-to-day sales operations.

 

What this new determination step does

When a user creates a transaction—an opportunity, lead, quote, order, or similar—the system looks for the owner directly on the account. That part is unchanged.

The new behavior kicks in when the account itself doesn’t have an assigned owner. Instead of stopping there or relying on manual intervention, the system now:

  1. Checks the account.

  2. If there’s no owner, moves one level up in the account hierarchy.

  3. Continues climbing to the parent, then the parent’s parent, all the way to the top.

  4. Stops as soon as it finds an owner.

  5. Assigns that owner to the transaction.

This gives companies a way to define ownership at the level that actually makes sense for their structure—whether that’s a subsidiary, a sub-division, or the global parent.

Why this matters

Here’s the thing. Many organizations have thousands of accounts, often organized into complex hierarchies. Maintaining individual owners at every level is unnecessary work. Teams end up doing manual corrections when ownership isn’t found or is outdated.

This new feature removes that burden.

It makes ownership deterministic, predictable, and aligned with the real business structure.
If a subsidiary doesn’t have a local sales rep assigned, the regional or global account manager automatically takes over. No gaps. No inconsistencies. No manual fixes.

A real-world example

Let’s look at a fictional company setup.

Example company: NovaTech Industries

NovaTech operates globally and has several regional subsidiaries.

  • NovaTech Global (Top Account)

    • NovaTech Europe

      • NovaTech Germany

        • NovaTech Berlin Office

      • NovaTech France

    • NovaTech APAC

      • NovaTech Japan

NovaTech assigns owners like this:

  • NovaTech Global: Sarah Kim, Global Account Director

  • NovaTech Europe: Lukas Steiner, Regional Sales Lead

  • NovaTech Germany: No owner assigned

  • NovaTech Berlin Office: No owner assigned

Now imagine a sales rep creates an opportunity for NovaTech Berlin Office. Before this enhancement, the system wouldn’t find an owner and might skip assignment or require manual correction.

With the new determination step activated:

  1. System checks NovaTech Berlin Office → no owner

  2. Moves to NovaTech Germany → still no owner

  3. Moves to NovaTech Europe → owner found (Lukas Steiner)

  4. Opportunity owner is set to Lukas automatically

No confusion. No backlogs. The transaction immediately flows to the right responsible person.

What this really means?

This new determination step closes one of the long-standing gaps in ownership assignment for transaction documents. It helps organizations keep data cleaner, removes dependence on manual fallbacks, and ensures every lead or opportunity is routed correctly even when account-level maintenance isn’t perfect.

The outcome is simple.
Sales teams spend less time fixing ownership issues and more time moving deals forward.

If you rely heavily on account hierarchies, activating this step can bring immediate clarity and reduce errors—especially in fast-scaling businesses or distributed sales organizations.

entry.title: RAG vs CAG: Choosing the Right Knowledge Augmentation Strategy for LLMs
entry.content:
Cache-Augmented Generation offers a compelling alternative to RAG's retrieval pipeline—eliminating latency overhead and achieving up to 40x faster generation times—but context window constraints limit its applicability to smaller, static knowledge bases. For data scientists evaluating these approaches, the choice hinges on a fundamental trade-off: CAG delivers superior speed and slightly higher accuracy for manageable datasets, while RAG remains the only viable option for enterprise-scale deployments with dynamic, evolving knowledge. The emergence of hybrid architectures in 2024-2025 now enables organizations to capture the benefits of both approaches through intelligent query routing

 

Introduction

Large Language Models have transformed how organizations interact with information, but their static training data creates a fundamental limitation: they cannot access current information or proprietary knowledge bases. This knowledge gap has driven the development of augmentation techniques that extend LLM capabilities by grounding responses in external data sources.

Retrieval-Augmented Generation emerged in 2020 as the dominant paradigm, combining information retrieval with text generation to enable LLMs to answer questions using custom document collections. The RAG ecosystem has since matured substantially, spawning an entire ecosystem of vector databases, embedding models, and orchestration frameworks. Yet according to industry analyses, approximately 72% of enterprise RAG implementations either fail outright or deliver significantly below expectations in their first year [1], prompting researchers to explore alternatives.

Cache-Augmented Generation represents a paradigm shift introduced in late 2024. Rather than retrieving relevant documents at query time, CAG preloads entire knowledge bases into the LLM's extended context window and caches the computational state for reuse across queries. This approach eliminates the retrieval pipeline entirely, promising simpler architectures and faster response times. Understanding when to deploy RAG, CAG, or hybrid approaches has become essential for organizations building knowledge-intensive AI applications.

 

What is RAG?

Retrieval-Augmented Generation is an AI framework that enhances Large Language Models by combining information retrieval with text generation. Instead of relying solely on knowledge encoded during training, RAG retrieves relevant information from external knowledge bases at inference time and incorporates it into the generation process.

The foundational paper, "Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Knowledge-Intensive NLP Tasks," was published by Patrick Lewis and collaborators at Facebook AI Research (now Meta AI) in May 2020 [2]. The researchers combined a pre-trained parametric memory (the seq2seq model BART) with non-parametric memory (a dense vector index of Wikipedia), demonstrating state-of-the-art results on open-domain question-answering tasks.

 

 

 

Core Architecture and Workflow

RAG systems operate through two distinct phases. The indexing phase occurs offline before any queries are processed: documents are loaded from various sources, broken into smaller chunks, converted into vector embeddings using models like OpenAI's text-embedding-3-small, and stored in vector databases such as SAP HANA. This preprocessing transforms unstructured documents into a searchable semantic index.

The inference phase activates when users submit queries. The system converts the query into a vector embedding using the same model that processed the documents, searches the vector database for semantically similar chunks, ranks the retrieved results by relevance, and constructs an augmented prompt combining the original query with retrieved context. The LLM then generates a response grounded in the provided information. A typical prompt structure instructs the model: "Using the CONTEXT provided, answer the QUESTION. Keep your answer grounded in the facts of the CONTEXT. If the CONTEXT doesn't contain the answer, say you don't know."

The RAG ecosystem has matured substantially since 2020. Orchestration frameworks like LangChain and LlamaIndex simplify pipeline construction.

 

Issues and Drawbacks of RAG

Despite widespread adoption, RAG systems face significant challenges across latency, accuracy, implementation complexity, and operational maintenance that explain the high enterprise failure rate.

 

Latency Overhead Compounds with Each Component

RAG introduces substantial performance penalties. Research published in December 2024 found that RAG-unique components account for 36-45% of end-to-end latency, with retrieval alone comprising 41% of response time [3]. In aggressive retrieval configurations, RAG overhead can reach 97% of total latency, pushing response times to approximately 30 seconds [3].

 

The "Lost in the Middle" Problem Undermines Long-Context Retrieval

Stanford and University of Washington researchers identified a critical accuracy issue: LLMs exhibit a U-shaped performance curve when processing retrieved context [4]. Performance is highest when relevant information appears at the beginning or end of the context window but degrades by more than 20% when key information falls in the middle. This persists even in models explicitly designed for long-context processing. The root cause traces to rotary position embedding introducing long-term decay that causes models to prioritize tokens at sequence boundaries.

 

Seven Documented Failure Points Reveal Systemic Vulnerabilities

Empirical research identified seven distinct failure modes in RAG systems [5]. Missing content occurs when answers simply don't exist in the knowledge base, yet the system generates plausible-sounding responses. Missed top-ranked documents happen when correct answers exist but don't rank highly enough to be retrieved within the top-K limitation. Consolidation failures arise when retrieved documents don't make it into the final context due to token limits. Extraction failures occur when the LLM fails to identify answers amid noisy or contradicting retrieved content.

 

Implementation Complexity Creates Combinatorial Tuning Challenges

Practitioners face what industry analysts describe as a "combinatorial explosion" of parameters requiring joint optimization: chunk size and overlap, embedding model selection, vector database configuration, top-K retrieval settings, reranking algorithms, context consolidation strategy, and prompt engineering. Finding optimal chunking strategies proves particularly difficult—chunks that are too small cannot answer certain questions, while chunks that are too large introduce noise.

 

Accuracy Degrades at Scale

Research by EyeLevel.ai found that vector similarity search precision degrades starting at 10,000 pages, with 12% accuracy loss by 100,000 pages [6]. As datastores grow, retrieval throughput can degrade significantly, presenting challenges for enterprise-scale deployments.

 

What is CAG?

Cache-Augmented Generation represents an alternative paradigm that bypasses real-time retrieval entirely. Introduced in December 2024 by Brian Chan, Chao-Ting Chen, Jui-Hung Cheng, and Hen-Hsen Huang in their paper "Don't Do RAG: When Cache-Augmented Generation is All You Need for Knowledge Tasks," [7] CAG leverages the extended context windows of modern LLMs to preload entire knowledge bases rather than retrieving subsets at query time.

 

 

The Three-Phase CAG Workflow

CAG operates through three distinct phases. During knowledge preloading, a curated collection of documents is preprocessed and formatted to fit within the model's context window. The LLM processes this collection, generating a precomputed Key-Value (KV) cache that encapsulates the inference state. This cache is stored persistently on disk or in memory, with computational cost incurred only once regardless of subsequent query volume.

During inference, the precomputed KV cache is loaded alongside each user query. The LLM utilizes this cached context to generate responses directly—no dynamic document fetching occurs. The combined prompt provides unified understanding of both knowledge and query, enabling the model to reason across the entire knowledge base simultaneously.

The cache reset phase addresses a practical concern: since KV caches grow in an append-only manner as new tokens are generated, resetting involves truncating newly appended tokens to return to the original cached state. This enables rapid reinitialization without reloading the entire cache from disk.

 

Understanding the KV Cache Mechanism

CAG extends the standard KV caching concept by precomputing the entire KV cache for the knowledge base—not just conversation history—and storing it persistently. At inference time, loading this pre-computed cache makes the "context" effectively free from a computational perspective. The model treats the entire knowledge base as if it were part of the conversation history, enabling full-context reasoning without retrieval.

 

Model Requirements for CAG Deployment

CAG requires long-context LLMs to be practical. Current frontier models supporting extended contexts include Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro and Flash with 1-2 million token windows, Claude models supporting 200K-1M tokens, GPT-4o with 128K tokens, and open-source options like Llama 3.1 with 128K token support. Research indicates that most models experience performance degradation before reaching advertised limits—a 128K window typically remains reliable to approximately 100K tokens in practice.

 

How CAG Addresses These Challenges

CAG's architectural simplicity eliminates several of RAG's fundamental pain points while introducing its own trade-offs.

 

Latency Reduction Through Retrieval Elimination

By removing the retrieval pipeline entirely, CAG achieves dramatic latency improvements. The original CAG paper demonstrated generation times of 0.85 seconds versus 9.25 seconds for small HotPotQA datasets—a 10.9x speedup [7]. For larger datasets (64 documents, 85K tokens), CAG completed in 2.33 seconds compared to 94.35 seconds without caching, representing a 40.5x improvement [7]. These gains come from eliminating query embedding computation, vector similarity search, document reranking, and context packaging steps that dominate RAG latency.

 

Accuracy Improvements from Complete Context Access

CAG consistently achieves higher accuracy than RAG configurations across benchmark datasets. On HotPotQA, CAG achieved BERTScore of 0.7759 versus 0.7516 for the best dense RAG configuration [7]. On SQuAD datasets, CAG scored 0.8265 compared to 0.8035 for dense RAG [7]. The advantage becomes more pronounced for multi-hop reasoning tasks requiring information synthesis across multiple documents—CAG has access to all documents simultaneously, while RAG may miss connecting information if the retriever fails to surface relevant chunks.

RAG particularly struggles with queries requiring multi-step reasoning, general queries where formulating retrieval queries is difficult, and implicit queries requiring whole-context understanding.

 

Architectural Simplicity Reduces Failure Modes

CAG eliminates several RAG failure points entirely. There are no retrieval misses because all documents are always present. Chunking strategy optimization becomes unnecessary. Embedding model selection and vector database tuning disappear as concerns. The combinatorial explosion of RAG parameters collapses to a simpler question: does your knowledge fit within the context window? This simplification reduces implementation time, operational complexity, and the surface area for system failures.

 

Side-by-Side Performance Evaluation

Empirical benchmarks reveal that neither approach dominates across all dimensions—the optimal choice depends on specific deployment requirements.

 

Metric

CAG Performance

RAG Performance

Winner

Generation latency

0.85-2.4s (after cache)

8-30s depending on configuration

CAG

Accuracy (BERTScore)

0.76-0.83

0.73-0.80

CAG (+2-4%)

Maximum corpus size

~128K tokens (~300 pages)

System complexity

Low (LLM only)

High (retriever + vector DB + orchestrator)

CAG

Scalability represents CAG's fundamental constraint. When researchers attempted CAG with 500+ documents on HotPotQA, the system encountered token limit errors [7]. RAG maintains consistent accuracy through selective retrieval regardless of total corpus size, making it the only viable option for enterprise knowledge bases spanning millions of documents.

 

Limitations of CAG

Understanding CAG's constraints is essential for appropriate deployment decisions.

 

Context Window Ceiling Creates Hard Knowledge Limits

Even with models supporting 128K or 1M token contexts, CAG cannot accommodate enterprise-scale knowledge bases. Web-scale corpora like Wikipedia's 3 billion words remain entirely infeasible. A 128K token window accommodates approximately 300 pages of text—substantial for focused applications but insufficient for organizations with multi-terabyte document repositories.

 

Memory and Compute Requirements Are Substantial

The KV cache grows linearly with context length and can exceed the size of model weights themselves at long contexts. Researchers reported that dual A100 40GB GPUs couldn't handle CAG scaling to larger knowledge bases, with the initial loading process proving "extremely memory-intensive." Standard attention has O(n²) complexity, making very long inputs computationally prohibitive. Production deployments often require 8-way tensor parallel setups across multiple GPUs to support both long contexts and reasonable concurrency.

 

Static Knowledge Creates Freshness Challenges

CAG's precomputed cache reflects knowledge at a single point in time. For dynamic domains—news, market data, legal compliance updates, inventory systems—cached knowledge becomes stale rapidly. Rebuilding caches for large knowledge bases requires substantial compute overhead, making CAG unsuitable for applications requiring dynamic updates or on-demand knowledge integration.

 

The "Lost in the Middle" Problem Persists

Despite having full context access, CAG inherits the same positional bias affecting all long-context LLM processing. Research confirms that information positioned in the middle of long contexts is more likely to be overlooked or poorly utilized, producing a U-shaped accuracy curve regardless of whether context arrived through retrieval or preloading [4].

 

Hybrid Approaches Combining CAG and RAG

The recognition that neither approach dominates across all scenarios has driven development of hybrid architectures that capture benefits from both paradigms.

 

 

Self-Route Enables Adaptive Query Handling

Research presented at EMNLP 2024 introduced Self-Route, an approach where the LLM self-reflects on whether queries are answerable with RAG alone [8]. The system presents retrieved chunks to the model, which evaluates whether the context is sufficient. If answerable, the system uses the lower-cost RAG response; if insufficient, it escalates to full long-context processing. For Gemini-1.5-Pro, 81.74% of queries were answered by RAG without escalation, achieving performance comparable to full long-context processing while using only 38.6% of tokens [8].

 

Tiered Architectures Serve Diverse Query Patterns

Organizations are implementing tiered systems that route queries based on characteristics. Core, frequently-accessed knowledge is preloaded via CAG for instant response times. Extended or dynamic knowledge is served through RAG with real-time retrieval. A retail example preloads product specifications via CAG for customer support while using RAG to fetch current promotions or inventory status. This architecture balances the efficiency of preloading with the flexibility of retrieval, enabling sub-second responses for common queries while maintaining access to the full knowledge corpus.

 

Foundation Context with Selective Retrieval

The original CAG paper proposed systems that "preload a foundation context and use retrieval only to augment edge cases or highly specific queries" [7]. This balances efficiency with flexibility—stable knowledge lives in the cache while the retrieval system handles novel or specialized information needs. The RAPTOR approach extends this by clustering documents into topics, generating high-level summaries for each cluster, caching summaries in the CAG layer, and fetching full documents on demand when deeper detail is required [9].

 

Conclusion

The emergence of Cache-Augmented Generation challenges assumptions that have dominated knowledge-augmented AI development since 2020. For applications with manageable, stable knowledge requirements where latency matters, CAG offers a compelling alternative: 10-40x faster generation times, 2-4% higher accuracy, and dramatically simpler architecture compared to RAG. The elimination of retrieval pipelines removes entire categories of failure modes that have frustrated enterprise deployments.

Yet RAG remains indispensable for the majority of production use cases. When knowledge bases span millions of documents, when information changes frequently, or when source attribution is required, RAG's selective retrieval approach proves essential.

The most significant development is the maturation of hybrid architectures that transcend the binary choice. Self-Route and similar approaches demonstrate that intelligent query routing can achieve long-context performance while using only 38.6% of tokens [8]. Tiered systems that combine CAG's speed for core knowledge with RAG's flexibility for extended corpora represent a practical path forward for organizations with diverse query patterns.

For data scientists evaluating these approaches, the decision framework has clarified: assess knowledge base size, update frequency, and latency requirements. Knowledge bases under 100K tokens with infrequent updates are strong CAG candidates. Enterprise-scale deployments with dynamic knowledge require RAG. Most organizations will benefit from hybrid architectures that route queries to the appropriate system based on complexity and freshness requirements.

 

 

I would like to thank Deepak Ram,  @Shubhojit-Sarkar, @Gokul10 for their Immense support and guidance. 

 

References

  2. Lewis, P., Perez, E., Piktus, A., Petroni, F., Karpukhin, V., Goyal, N., Küttler, H., Lewis, M., Yih, W., Rocktäschel, T., Riedel, S., & Kiela, D. (2020). entry.title: CDS Activation Resets Sequences — Causing Go-Live Blocker
entry.content:
Hi Community,

We are facing a critical issue in our on-premise SAP HANA system, and I would appreciate your guidance or any known solutions.

Issue Summary

Whenever we activate CDS artifacts (e.g., .hdbdd / .hdbtable definitions), all related HANA sequences are getting reset.
After activation, the sequence values restart, which forces us to manually run ALTER SEQUENCE statements to restore the correct value.

This behavior is impacting deployments in QA and Production, and is currently a go-live blocker.

Technical Details

  • Platform: SAP BTP NEO

  • Application Stack: XS Classic (XSJS), SAPUI5, CDS Views

Any help, similar experiences, or SAP Notes related to this would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Sai Mekala

entry.title: BOライセンスキー発行手順
entry.content:
SAP for MeでのBOのライセンスキー発行方法の確認になります。
数日前からサイトが急に変更されており、ライセンスキーが発行できない状況です。
どのように発行すればよろしいでしょうか。

以前は、

　URL />

　URL />

entry.title: Re: BOライセンスキー発行手順
entry.content:
以下の手順にて申請していただけますでしょうか。

1、[SAP for Me] - [システムおよびプロビジョニング] - [キー] - [ライセンスキー] を開きます。

リンク：https://me.sap.com/licensekeys/installations/installations

2、「Installation」より、ライセンスキー発行申請の対象となるインストール番号を指定してください。

3、「Add System」ボタンをクリックします。

◆Add New System 画面の操作

「Software Product」及びそのバージョンを選択し、「System ID」「System Role」「Operating System」の項目に必要事項を入力・選択した上で、「Continue」をクリックしてください。

◆Create License Key Request 画面の操作

以下の情報をすべて指定した後、「Save」をクリックして保存してください。

・Material
・Version
・Number of Licenses
・Expiry Date

詳細について記載されているドキュメントをお送りいたしますので、ご参考になれば幸いです。
https://support.sap.com/content/dam/support/en_us/library/ssp/my-support/keys/license-key-help/new-request-license-keys-bobj.pdf

上記内容について何か不明な点や懸念事項などがございましたら、お気軽にご返信ください。
